title: Jacques Guy
text:
Jacques Guy (born 23 November 1944) is a French linguist, living in <a href="Australia">Australia</a> since 1968. He started undergraduate studies at the École des Langues Orientales (School of Oriental Languages, renamed since to the <a href="Institut%20national%20des%20langues%20et%20civilisations%20orientales">Institut national des langues et civilisations orientales</a>) in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, France, focusing on <a href="Chinese%20language">Chinese</a>, <a href="Japanese%20language">Japanese</a> and <a href="Tahitian%20language">Tahitian</a>. He wrote his Ph.D. thesis, under the auspices of the <a href="Australian%20National%20University">Australian National University</a>, on <a href="Sakao%20language">Sakao</a>, a dialect of <a href="Espiritu%20Santo">Espiritu Santo</a> (located in the island group then called the <a href="New%20Hebrides">New Hebrides</a> and now called <a href="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>). 
Following this, he turned his attention towards automatic text manipulation and to digital taxonomy, working from 1985 at the AI research lab of Telecom Australia (<a href="Telstra">Telstra</a>) in Clayton, a suburb of <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>. He remained at Telstra until 1998. His work led him to take an interest in two linguistic enigmas: <a href="Rongorongo">Rongorongo</a> and the <a href="Voynich%20manuscript">Voynich manuscript</a>.
